How to Coordinate Edge Devices for Over-the-Air Federated Learning?

Mohammad Ali Sedaghat1, Ali Bereyhi2, Saba Asaad2, and Ralf R. Müller2, 1Qualcomm CDMA Technologies GmbH Nuremberg
2Friedrich-Alexander Universität Erlangen-Nürnberg (FAU)
msedagha@qti.qualcomm.com, {ali.bereyhi, saba.asaad, ralf.r.mueller}@fau.de
Abstract

This work studies the task of device coordination in wireless networks for over-the-air federated learning (OTA-FL). For conventional metrics of aggregation error, the task is shown to describe the zero-forcing (ZF) and minimum mean squared error (MMSE) schemes and reduces to the NP-hard problem of subset selection. We tackle this problem by studying properties of the optimal scheme. Our analytical results reveal that this scheme is found by searching among the leaves of a tree with favorable monotonic features. Invoking these features, we develop a low-complexity algorithm that approximates the optimal scheme by tracking a dominant path of the tree sequentially. Our numerical investigations show that the proposed algorithm closely tracks the optimal scheme.

Index Terms:
Over-the-air communication, federated Learning, multi-antenna, mean squared error.

I Introduction

Federated learning (FL) is a privacy-preserving framework for distributed learning that enables edge devices to address a learning task, e.g., training a global model, jointly without need for sharing their local data [1, 2, 3]. This ensures device privacy and provides a joint scheme for learning that performs considerably better than individual distributed learning while keeping the communication load of the system tractable [4, 5, 6].

The promising learning performance in FL comes along with several challenges which are roughly divided into the three categories of privacy, statistical properties of local datasets and communication-efficiency. With respect to privacy, FL has been shown to be vulnerable against model inversion attack [7, 8]. This follows from the fact that edge devices in FL share their local models that are often strongly correlated with their local data [9, 10]. Statistical properties of local datasets further refers to the sensitivity of FL against data distribution. Initial studies on FL have shown promising performance and fast convergence of this framework for homogeneous local datasets. Nevertheless, obtaining these favorable behaviors have been shown to face some analytical challenges when we deviate from simple statistical models for local datasets [11]. This is in particular crucial, as the exact statistical model of data is rather unknown in practice.

This study focuses on the latter class of challenges in FL, i.e., communication-efficiency, that refers to communication-related challenges, when the FL framework is to be implemented in a wireless network. In fact, FL schemes require several rounds of communication between a central node, often called the parameter server (PS), and the edge devices. This is in particular challenging when the scheme runs over remote wireless devices introducing various sources of imperfection to the setting, e.g., rate-limited communication links and noisy assessment of local model parameters [12, 13, 14].

I-A Over-the-Air Federated Learning

FL performs distributed learning in three main phases:

  1. 1.

    Starting with an initial global model, edge devices learn a model locally from their datasets. They then share the local models with the PS.

  2. 2.

    The PS collects the local models and aggregates them into a global model.

  3. 3.

    The global model is sent back to the devices, and the devices repeat local learning via the new global model.

The PS and edge devices keep iterating these three phases for several communication rounds until they converge.

Classical approaches for implementation of FL in a wireless network suggest a separate decoding and aggregation at the PS[15, 16]. This means that the PS decodes first the received local models and then combines the decoded models into a global model via a predefined aggregation policy. An alternative approach is proposed in [17] which invokes the idea of analog function computation [18] to perform model aggregation directly over the air. We refer to this latter approach as over-the-air FL (OTA-FL) in this paper. OTA-FL invokes the signal combination in the multiple access channel to realize the predefined aggregation policy directly over-the-air. In other words, the edge devices in OTA-FL transmit their local models with proper scaling, such the desired model aggregation is calculated from the a linearly-transformed version of the received signal at the PS. In various use-cases, OTA-FL is more efficient than separate decoding and aggregation [19]. In fact, OTA-FL does not need to orthogonalize communication resources, i.e., allocate individual bandwidth and time slot to every device, and hence it enjoys both advantages of lower computation and resource efficiency [20, 21, 22].

I-B Contributions and Organization

As OTA-FL relies on the uplink channel for model aggregation, coordination plays a key role in its performance. In fact, the PS and devices need to agree on a communication protocol, such that the over-the-air aggregated model is as close as possible to the desired form. Prior studies often consider a basic approach for coordination that is known to be sub-optimal from the information theoretic point of view. In this work, we study the concept of coordination in OTA-FL in great details. In this respect, we first formulate an optimal coordination scheme for a given metric of aggregation error mathematically. We then show that using the conventional metric of mean squared error (MSE) for aggregation error, the optimal coordination scheme reduces to an MSE minimization problem, while the commonly-used strategy for coordination is simply zero-forcing. Our analyses show that both strategies reduce to the NP-hard problem of subset selection and hence deal with the same level of hardness. We tackle the problem of subset selection in both minimum MSE and zero-forcing schemes by studying the properties of the solution. Our investigations reveal that the solution in both cases can be found by searching over the leaves of a tree with some monotonic properties. In the light of these properties, we propose low-complexity algorithms which sequentially approximate the solution by tracking a dominant path towards leaves. Our simulation results show that the proposed tree-based algorithm can track the optimal performance very closely while enjoying a drastically lower computational complexity.

The remaining of this manuscript is organized as follows: We first formulate the problem concretely in Section II. Minimum MSE and zero-forcing coordination schemes are then illustrated in Sections III and IV , respectively. Sections V and VI investigates the analytical properties of the zero-forcing and minimum MSE schemes, respectively, and propose a tree-based algorithm for their approximation with low complexity. The validity of the derivations are confirmed through numerical investigation in Section VII. Finally, Section VIII concludes the paper.

II Problem Formulation

A wireless network with L𝐿L single-antenna edge devices and a PS is considered. The devices employ an FL scheme, e.g., federated averaging, to address a common learning task, e.g., training a given model, jointly over their distributed local datasets. The PS is equipped with an N𝑁N-element array-antenna. Throughout the analyses, we assume that N≥L𝑁𝐿N\geq L. This assumption is however taken for the sake of brevity. The case of N<L𝑁𝐿N<L is then discussed separately as a remark; see Remark 1.

At the beginning of each coherence interval, the devices send predefined pilots in their uplink channels. The PS then estimates the channel state information (CSI) based on the received signals. For simplicity, we assume that the pilots are mutually orthogonal and that the estimation error is negligible. Hence, the PS knows the CSI perfectly. Throughout the analyses, we assume that the channels experience frequency-flat fading processes. This models transmission over a channel with a narrow frequency band. The derivations are in principle extendable to wide-band transmission in multi-carrier systems with frequency selective fading processes.

II-A OTA-FL Setting

Following the FL scheme, each device determines its local model parameters from its local dataset. It then shares this local model with the PS through its uplink channel. Let sℓsubscript𝑠ℓs_{\ell} be the model parameter of device ℓℓ\ell that is to be shared with the PS in a given time-frequency slot. Device ℓℓ\ell transmits this parameter by applying a channel-dependent scaling coefficient bℓsubscript𝑏ℓb_{\ell}, i.e., it transmits

xℓ=bℓ​sℓ.subscript𝑥ℓsubscript𝑏ℓsubscript𝑠ℓ\displaystyle x_{\ell}=b_{\ell}s_{\ell}. (1)

The local models {sℓ}subscript𝑠ℓ\left\{s_{\ell}\right\} are assumed to be independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.) with mean zero and unit variance111Note that in practice {sℓ}subscript𝑠ℓ\left\{s_{\ell}\right\} are unbiased versions of the model parameters, e.g., quantized gradient values, which for weakly-correlated local datasets fit into this model [23].. The devices are further restricted to set their average power below a maximum power P𝑃P. This means that over a period of time in which the channel is approximately constant, the transmit signal of device ℓℓ\ell satisfies

ℰ​{|xℓ|2}=|bℓ|2≤P.ℰsuperscriptsubscript𝑥ℓ2superscriptsubscript𝑏ℓ2𝑃\displaystyle\mathcal{E}\left\{\left|x_{\ell}\right|^{2}\right\}=\left|b_{\ell}\right|^{2}\leq P. (2)

The devices communicate over a fading Gaussian MAC. Hence, the PS receives 𝐲∈ℂN𝐲superscriptℂ𝑁\mathbf{y}\in\mathbb{C}^{N} which is given by

𝐲=∑ℓ=1L𝐡ℓ​xℓ+𝐧.𝐲superscriptsubscriptℓ1𝐿subscript𝐡ℓsubscript𝑥ℓ𝐧\displaystyle\mathbf{y}=\sum_{\ell=1}^{L}\mathbf{h}_{\ell}x_{\ell}+\mathbf{n}. (3)

Here, 𝐡ℓ∈ℂNsubscript𝐡ℓsuperscriptℂ𝑁\mathbf{h}_{\ell}\in\mathbb{C}^{N} denotes the complex uplink channel vector of device ℓℓ\ell, and 𝐧∈ℂN𝐧superscriptℂ𝑁\mathbf{n}\in\mathbb{C}^{N} is additive white Gaussian noise with mean zero and variance σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}, i.e., 𝐧∼𝒩​(𝟎,σ2​𝐈N)similar-to𝐧𝒩0superscript𝜎2subscript𝐈𝑁\mathbf{n}\sim\mathcal{N}\left(\boldsymbol{0},\sigma^{2}\mathbf{I}_{N}\right).

The ultimate goal of the PS is to combine the local models according to a predefined strategy specified by the FL scheme. More precisely, the PS aims to determine

θ=∑ℓ=1Lϕℓ​sℓ𝜃superscriptsubscriptℓ1𝐿subscriptitalic-ϕℓsubscript𝑠ℓ\displaystyle\theta=\sum_{\ell=1}^{L}\phi_{\ell}s_{\ell} (4)

for some predefined coefficients {ϕℓ}subscriptitalic-ϕℓ\left\{\phi_{\ell}\right\}, and then share it with the devices through its downlink channels. To this end, the PS invokes the idea of OTA-FL and combines the local models directly over-the-air: it estimates the desired global model, i.e., θ𝜃\theta, by combining the received signal elements. In other words, it employs a linear receiver 𝐦∈ℂN𝐦superscriptℂ𝑁\mathbf{m}\in\mathbb{C}^{N} and determines an estimate of θ𝜃\theta as

θ^=𝐦𝖳​𝐲^𝜃superscript𝐦𝖳𝐲\displaystyle\hat{\theta}=\mathbf{m}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{y} =∑ℓ=1L𝐦𝖳​𝐡ℓ​xℓ+𝐦𝖳​𝐧,absentsuperscriptsubscriptℓ1𝐿superscript𝐦𝖳subscript𝐡ℓsubscript𝑥ℓsuperscript𝐦𝖳𝐧\displaystyle=\sum_{\ell=1}^{L}\mathbf{m}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{h}_{\ell}x_{\ell}+\mathbf{m}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{n}, (5)
=∑ℓ=1L𝐦𝖳​𝐡ℓ​bℓ​sℓ+𝐦𝖳​𝐧.absentsuperscriptsubscriptℓ1𝐿superscript𝐦𝖳subscript𝐡ℓsubscript𝑏ℓsubscript𝑠ℓsuperscript𝐦𝖳𝐧\displaystyle=\sum_{\ell=1}^{L}\mathbf{m}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{h}_{\ell}b_{\ell}s_{\ell}+\mathbf{m}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{n}. (6)

It is readily to shown that by restricting the estimation at the PS to be linear, the OTA-FL scheme is optimal: there exists a receiver 𝐦𝐦\mathbf{m} and scaling coefficients bℓsubscript𝑏ℓb_{\ell} whose corresponding estimate of global model, i.e., θ^^𝜃\hat{\theta} in (6), recovers the estimate achieved by combining the optimal linear estimation of local models according to the predefined strategy in (4) [17].

II-B Aggregation Error of the OTA-FL Setting

As communication is carried out through a noisy network, the estimated global model θ^^𝜃\hat{\theta} contains some error as compared with the desired global model θ𝜃\theta. This error is often called aggregation error and can be evaluated in various respect. The classical approach in OTA-FL is to quantify the aggregation error in terms of the mean squared error (MSE).

Using the MSE as the metric, the aggregation error in this setting is given by

ϵ​(𝐦,{bℓ})italic-ϵ𝐦subscript𝑏ℓ\displaystyle\epsilon\left(\mathbf{m},\left\{b_{\ell}\right\}\right) =ℰ​{|θ^−θ|2},absentℰsuperscript^𝜃𝜃2\displaystyle=\mathcal{E}\left\{\left|\hat{\theta}-\theta\right|^{2}\right\}, (7)
=ℰ​{|∑ℓ=1L(𝐦𝖳​𝐡ℓ​bℓ−ϕℓ)​sℓ+𝐦𝖳​𝐧|2},absentℰsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptℓ1𝐿superscript𝐦𝖳subscript𝐡ℓsubscript𝑏ℓsubscriptitalic-ϕℓsubscript𝑠ℓsuperscript𝐦𝖳𝐧2\displaystyle=\mathcal{E}\left\{\left|\sum_{\ell=1}^{L}\left(\mathbf{m}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{h}_{\ell}b_{\ell}-\phi_{\ell}\right)s_{\ell}+\mathbf{m}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{n}\right|^{2}\right\}, (8)
=∑ℓ=1L|𝐦𝖳​𝐡ℓ​bℓ−ϕℓ|2+σ2​‖𝐦‖2.absentsuperscriptsubscriptℓ1𝐿superscriptsuperscript𝐦𝖳subscript𝐡ℓsubscript𝑏ℓsubscriptitalic-ϕℓ2superscript𝜎2superscriptnorm𝐦2\displaystyle=\sum_{\ell=1}^{L}\left|\mathbf{m}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{h}_{\ell}b_{\ell}-\phi_{\ell}\right|^{2}+\sigma^{2}\left\|\mathbf{m}\right\|^{2}. (9)

The error expression can be compactly represented as

ϵ​(𝐦,𝐁)italic-ϵ𝐦𝐁\displaystyle\epsilon\left(\mathbf{m},\mathbf{B}\right) =‖𝐁𝐇𝖳​𝐦−ϕ‖2+σ2​‖𝐦‖2absentsuperscriptnormsuperscript𝐁𝐇𝖳𝐦bold-italic-ϕ2superscript𝜎2superscriptnorm𝐦2\displaystyle=\left\|\mathbf{B}\mathbf{H}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{m}-\boldsymbol{\phi}\right\|^{2}+\sigma^{2}\left\|\mathbf{m}\right\|^{2} (10)

where 𝐁=Diag​{bℓ}𝐁Diagsubscript𝑏ℓ\mathbf{B}=\mathrm{Diag}\left\{b_{\ell}\right\}, ϕ=[ϕ1,…,ϕL]𝖳italic-ϕsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ1…subscriptitalic-ϕ𝐿𝖳\phi=\left[\phi_{1},\ldots,\phi_{L}\right]^{\mathsf{T}} and 𝐇𝐇\mathbf{H} is the uplink channel matrix, i.e.,

𝐇=[𝐡1,…,𝐡L].𝐇subscript𝐡1…subscript𝐡𝐿\displaystyle\mathbf{H}=\left[\mathbf{h}_{1},\ldots,\mathbf{h}_{L}\right]. (11)

II-C Coordination Schemes for the OTA-FL Setting

To establish FL in the network, the PS needs to coordinate the devices periodically: after the uplink training phase at the beginning of a coherence interval, the PS specifies the uplink scaling coefficients of the devices, i.e., {bℓ}subscript𝑏ℓ\left\{b_{\ell}\right\}, and the linear receiver 𝐦𝐦\mathbf{m}. The devices are then informed about their scaling coefficients by a downlink transmission. Afterwards, throughout the coherence interval, the PS and devices carry out their communication according to the OTA-FL scheme described in Section II-A using the coefficients and receiver specified in the training phase. It is worth mentioning that the PS only shares the scaling coefficients with the devices and not the complete CSI.

In general, the optimality of a coordination strategy depends on the choice of metric that determines the quality of the FL scheme. A good approach is to consider the aggregation error as the metric and design the coordination strategy, such that the error is minimized222This is in particular effective, since the MSE of estimated global model directly affects the learning quality of the FL scheme [17].. In this case, the optimal coordination strategy is formulated as

(𝐦⋆,𝐁⋆)=argmin𝐦∈ℂN,|bℓ|2≤Pϵ​(𝐦,𝐁).superscript𝐦⋆superscript𝐁⋆subscriptargminformulae-sequence𝐦superscriptℂ𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑏ℓ2𝑃italic-ϵ𝐦𝐁\displaystyle\left(\mathbf{m}^{\star},\mathbf{B}^{\star}\right)=\operatorname*{argmin}_{\mathbf{m}\in\mathbb{C}^{N},\left|b_{\ell}\right|^{2}\leq P}\epsilon\left(\mathbf{m},\mathbf{B}\right). (12)

This is in fact a minimum MSE (MMSE) problem. We hence refer to this strategy as MMSE coordination. Due to its non-convexity, MMSE coordination is computationally intractable in a generic network.

An alternative approach for coordination is to use the idea of zero-forcing (ZF) [17, 24]. In this approach, the PS ignores noise in the channel and coordinates the devices, such that the noise-free version of the estimated global model constructs the desired global model. From (6), this means that the PS finds 𝐦𝐦\mathbf{m} and {bℓ}subscript𝑏ℓ\left\{b_{\ell}\right\}, such that

𝐦𝖳​𝐡ℓ​bℓ=ϕℓ.superscript𝐦𝖳subscript𝐡ℓsubscript𝑏ℓsubscriptitalic-ϕℓ\displaystyle\mathbf{m}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{h}_{\ell}b_{\ell}=\phi_{\ell}. (13)

In this case, the aggregation error reduces to

ϵ​(𝐦,𝐁)=σ2​‖𝐦‖2.italic-ϵ𝐦𝐁superscript𝜎2superscriptnorm𝐦2\displaystyle\epsilon\left(\mathbf{m},\mathbf{B}\right)=\sigma^{2}\left\|\mathbf{m}\right\|^{2}. (14)

The PS hence solves the following problem

𝐦zf=superscript𝐦zfabsent\displaystyle\mathbf{m}^{\rm zf}= argmin𝐦∈ℂN‖𝐦‖2subscriptargmin𝐦superscriptℂ𝑁superscriptnorm𝐦2\displaystyle\operatorname*{argmin}_{\mathbf{m}\in\mathbb{C}^{N}}\left\|\mathbf{m}\right\|^{2} (15)
subject to​|ϕℓ𝐦𝖳​𝐡ℓ|2≤P​ for ​ℓ∈[L],subject tosuperscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕℓsuperscript𝐦𝖳subscript𝐡ℓ2𝑃 for ℓdelimited-[]𝐿\displaystyle\text{subject to}\;\left|\frac{\phi_{\ell}}{\mathbf{m}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{h}_{\ell}}\right|^{2}\leq P\;\text{ for }\;\ell\in\left[L\right],

to find the receiver. The scaling coefficients {bℓ}subscript𝑏ℓ\left\{b_{\ell}\right\} are then determined from (13) by replacing 𝐦𝐦\mathbf{m} with 𝐦zfsuperscript𝐦zf\mathbf{m}^{\rm zf}, i.e.,

bℓzf=ϕℓ𝐡ℓ𝖳​𝐦zfsuperscriptsubscript𝑏ℓzfsubscriptitalic-ϕℓsuperscriptsubscript𝐡ℓ𝖳superscript𝐦zf\displaystyle b_{\ell}^{\rm zf}=\frac{\phi_{\ell}}{\mathbf{h}_{\ell}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{m}^{\rm zf}} (16)

In the sequel, we refer to this scheme as ZF coordination.

III MMSE Coordination for OTA-FL

The design problem for MMSE coordination is non-convex and generally challenging to solve. Nevertheless, for some particular cases, the solution can be derived tractably. An instance is given in [25], where the solution of a mathematically similar problem is derived for an uplink scenario with a single-antenna PS in closed form, despite its non-convexity. Motivated by this result, we present in the sequel some preliminary analyses. We show that the problem in the general case with a multi-antenna PS is more complicated and unlike the single-antenna case, the optimal MMSE scheme cannot be derived analytically. The analyses however give some important insights on MMSE coordination that pave the way for the proposed algorithms in next sections. We start the analyses by the following lemma:

Lemma 1.

With MMSE coordination in the network, there is at least one device that transmits with the maximum transmit power P𝑃P.

Proof.

The proof is given by contradiction: assume that all the devices transmit with power less than P𝑃P while coordinated via the MMSE scheme in (12). Let 𝐦⋆superscript𝐦⋆\mathbf{m}^{\star} and {bℓ⋆}superscriptsubscript𝑏ℓ⋆\left\{b_{\ell}^{\star}\right\} refer to the solutions of the MMSE scheme. This means that |bℓ⋆|2<Psuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑏ℓ⋆2𝑃\left|b_{\ell}^{\star}\right|^{2}<P. We now construct new scaling coefficients as b^ℓ=κ​bℓ⋆subscript^𝑏ℓ𝜅superscriptsubscript𝑏ℓ⋆\hat{b}_{\ell}=\kappa b_{\ell}^{\star}, where κ>1𝜅1\kappa>1 is chosen such that

maxℓ∈[L]⁡|b^ℓ|2=P.subscriptℓdelimited-[]𝐿superscriptsubscript^𝑏ℓ2𝑃\displaystyle\max_{\ell\in\left[L\right]}\left|\hat{b}_{\ell}\right|^{2}=P. (17)

A new receiver is further constructed from 𝐦⋆superscript𝐦⋆\mathbf{m}^{\star} as 𝐦^=κ−1​𝐦⋆^𝐦superscript𝜅1superscript𝐦⋆\hat{\mathbf{m}}=\kappa^{-1}\mathbf{m}^{\star} and satisfies ‖𝐦^‖<‖𝐦⋆‖norm^𝐦normsuperscript𝐦⋆\left\|\hat{\mathbf{m}}\right\|<\left\|\mathbf{m}^{\star}\right\|.

We now consider the aggregation error derived in (9). Using the new scaling coefficients and receiver, i.e., 𝐦^^𝐦\hat{\mathbf{m}} and {b^ℓ}subscript^𝑏ℓ\{\hat{b}_{\ell}\}, the first term in the error expression remains unchanged as compared with the term given for 𝐦⋆superscript𝐦⋆\mathbf{m}^{\star} and {bℓ⋆}superscriptsubscript𝑏ℓ⋆\left\{b_{\ell}^{\star}\right\}. The second term however becomes smaller. This means that we have found 𝐦^^𝐦\hat{\mathbf{m}} and {b^ℓ}subscript^𝑏ℓ\{\hat{b}_{\ell}\} that satisfy

ϵ​(𝐦^,{b^ℓ})≤ϵ​(𝐦⋆,{bℓ⋆}).italic-ϵ^𝐦subscript^𝑏ℓitalic-ϵsuperscript𝐦⋆superscriptsubscript𝑏ℓ⋆\displaystyle\epsilon(\hat{\mathbf{m}},\{\hat{b}_{\ell}\})\leq\epsilon\left(\mathbf{m}^{\star},\{b_{\ell}^{\star}\}\right). (18)

This contradicts with the definition of MMSE coordination in (12), and hence concludes the proof333A similar result has been shown in [25] for a single-antenna PS.. ∎

Lemma 1 implies that with MMSE coordination, at least one device is transmitting with the maximum power. From this result, we can have a simple conclusion: let the set of devices [L]delimited-[]𝐿\left[L\right] be partitioned as [L]=𝔻∪𝔻¯delimited-[]𝐿𝔻¯𝔻\left[L\right]=\mathbb{D}\cup\bar{\mathbb{D}}, where 𝔻𝔻\mathbb{D} denotes the set of all devices transmitting with the maximum power P𝑃P and 𝔻¯¯𝔻\bar{\mathbb{D}} represents the complement of 𝔻𝔻\mathbb{D} including all devices whose transmit powers are less than P𝑃P. Lemma 1 indicates that 𝔻𝔻\mathbb{D} is always non-empty, i.e., it contains at least one device. In general, there can be more than a single device in 𝔻𝔻\mathbb{D}.

We next state Lemma 2 which describes a key property of the devices in 𝔻¯¯𝔻\bar{\mathbb{D}}:

Lemma 2.

Let 𝐦⋆superscript𝐦⋆\mathbf{m}^{\star} and {bℓ⋆}superscriptsubscript𝑏ℓ⋆\left\{b_{\ell}^{\star}\right\} be given by MMSE coordination. For any ℓ∈𝔻¯ℓ¯𝔻\ell\in\bar{\mathbb{D}}, i.e., any device transmitting with power less than P𝑃P, bℓ⋆superscriptsubscript𝑏ℓ⋆b_{\ell}^{\star} satisfies

bℓ⋆=ϕℓ𝐡ℓ𝖳​𝐦⋆.superscriptsubscript𝑏ℓ⋆subscriptitalic-ϕℓsuperscriptsubscript𝐡ℓ𝖳superscript𝐦⋆\displaystyle b_{\ell}^{\star}=\frac{\phi_{\ell}}{\mathbf{h}_{\ell}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{m}^{\star}}.
Proof.

The proof is given by contradiction following similar steps taken in the proof of 1. We hence skip the details. ∎

To understand this result, let us consider the aggregation error in (9). Lemma 1 indicates that with MMSE coordination, the components in the first term of the aggregation error that correspond to the devices in 𝔻¯¯𝔻\bar{\mathbb{D}}, i.e.,

|𝐦⋆𝖳​𝐡ℓ​bℓ⋆−ϕℓ|2=0.superscriptsuperscript𝐦⋆absent𝖳subscript𝐡ℓsubscriptsuperscript𝑏⋆ℓsubscriptitalic-ϕℓ20\displaystyle\left|\mathbf{m}^{\star\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{h}_{\ell}b^{\star}_{\ell}-\phi_{\ell}\right|^{2}=0. (19)

In other words, for these devices, MMSE coordination is similar to ZF, c.f. (16), and only the devices in 𝔻𝔻\mathbb{D}, i.e., those who transmit with power P𝑃P, contribute to the first term of the aggregation error.

We next connect the receiver given by MMSE coordination, i.e., 𝐦⋆superscript𝐦⋆\mathbf{m}^{\star}, to the devices in 𝔻𝔻\mathbb{D}.

Lemma 3.

Let 𝐦⋆superscript𝐦⋆\mathbf{m}^{\star} be given by MMSE coordination. Then, there exists complex scalars αℓsubscript𝛼ℓ\alpha_{\ell} for ℓ∈𝔻ℓ𝔻\ell\in\mathbb{D}, such that

𝐦⋆=∑ℓ∈𝔻αℓ​𝐡ℓ.superscript𝐦⋆subscriptℓ𝔻subscript𝛼ℓsubscript𝐡ℓ\displaystyle\mathbf{m}^{\star}=\sum_{\ell\in\mathbb{D}}\alpha_{\ell}\mathbf{h}_{\ell}. (20)
Proof.

The proof follows the results of Lemmas 1 and 2. From Lemma 2, we know that

ϵ​(𝐦⋆,{bℓ⋆})italic-ϵsuperscript𝐦⋆superscriptsubscript𝑏ℓ⋆\displaystyle\epsilon\left(\mathbf{m}^{\star},\left\{b_{\ell}^{\star}\right\}\right) =∑ℓ∈𝔻|𝐦⋆𝖳​𝐡ℓ​bℓ⋆−ϕℓ|2+σ2​‖𝐦⋆‖2.absentsubscriptℓ𝔻superscriptsuperscript𝐦⋆absent𝖳subscript𝐡ℓsubscriptsuperscript𝑏⋆ℓsubscriptitalic-ϕℓ2superscript𝜎2superscriptnormsuperscript𝐦⋆2\displaystyle=\sum_{\ell\in\mathbb{D}}\left|\mathbf{m}^{\star\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{h}_{\ell}b^{\star}_{\ell}-\phi_{\ell}\right|^{2}+\sigma^{2}\left\|\mathbf{m}^{\star}\right\|^{2}. (21)

Lemma 1 further implies that for ℓ∈𝔻ℓ𝔻\ell\in\mathbb{D}, the scaling coefficient is bℓ⋆=P​ej​φℓsubscriptsuperscript𝑏⋆ℓ𝑃superscriptejsubscript𝜑ℓb^{\star}_{\ell}=\sqrt{P}\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{j}\varphi_{\ell}} for some phase φℓsubscript𝜑ℓ\varphi_{\ell}. Hence, we can write

ϵ​(𝐦⋆,{bℓ⋆})italic-ϵsuperscript𝐦⋆superscriptsubscript𝑏ℓ⋆\displaystyle\epsilon\left(\mathbf{m}^{\star},\left\{b_{\ell}^{\star}\right\}\right) =∑ℓ∈𝔻|𝐦⋆𝖳​𝐡ℓ​P​ej​φℓ−ϕℓ|2+σ2​‖𝐦⋆‖2absentsubscriptℓ𝔻superscriptsuperscript𝐦⋆absent𝖳subscript𝐡ℓ𝑃superscriptejsubscript𝜑ℓsubscriptitalic-ϕℓ2superscript𝜎2superscriptnormsuperscript𝐦⋆2\displaystyle=\sum_{\ell\in\mathbb{D}}\left|\mathbf{m}^{\star\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{h}_{\ell}\sqrt{P}\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{j}\varphi_{\ell}}-\phi_{\ell}\right|^{2}+\sigma^{2}\left\|\mathbf{m}^{\star}\right\|^{2}
≤∑ℓ∈𝔻|𝐦𝖳​𝐡ℓ​P​ej​φℓ−ϕℓ|2+σ2​‖𝐦‖2absentsubscriptℓ𝔻superscriptsuperscript𝐦𝖳subscript𝐡ℓ𝑃superscriptejsubscript𝜑ℓsubscriptitalic-ϕℓ2superscript𝜎2superscriptnorm𝐦2\displaystyle\leq\sum_{\ell\in\mathbb{D}}\left|\mathbf{m}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{h}_{\ell}\sqrt{P}\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{j}\varphi_{\ell}}-\phi_{\ell}\right|^{2}+\sigma^{2}\left\|\mathbf{m}\right\|^{2} (22)

for any 𝐦∈ℂN𝐦superscriptℂ𝑁\mathbf{m}\in\mathbb{C}^{N}. Note that φℓ=−ϑℓsubscript𝜑ℓsubscriptitalic-ϑℓ\varphi_{\ell}=-\vartheta_{\ell} with ϑℓsubscriptitalic-ϑℓ\vartheta_{\ell} being the phase of 𝐦⋆𝖳​𝐡ℓsuperscript𝐦⋆absent𝖳subscript𝐡ℓ\mathbf{m}^{\star\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{h}_{\ell}.

From (22), we can conclude that 𝐦⋆superscript𝐦⋆\mathbf{m}^{\star} is the solution to444Note that we can set φℓ=0subscript𝜑ℓ0\varphi_{\ell}=0 without loss of generality.

min𝐦∈ℂN​∑ℓ∈𝔻|𝐦𝖳​𝐡ℓ​P−ϕℓ|2+σ2​‖𝐦‖2subscript𝐦superscriptℂ𝑁subscriptℓ𝔻superscriptsuperscript𝐦𝖳subscript𝐡ℓ𝑃subscriptitalic-ϕℓ2superscript𝜎2superscriptnorm𝐦2\displaystyle\min_{\mathbf{m}\in\mathbb{C}^{N}}\sum_{\ell\in\mathbb{D}}\left|\mathbf{m}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{h}_{\ell}\sqrt{P}-\phi_{\ell}\right|^{2}+\sigma^{2}\left\|\mathbf{m}\right\|^{2} (23)

that describes a regularized ZF problem. This implies that 𝐦⋆superscript𝐦⋆\mathbf{m}^{\star} only linearly depends on {𝐡ℓ:ℓ∈𝔻}conditional-setsubscript𝐡ℓℓ𝔻\left\{\mathbf{h}_{\ell}:\ell\in\mathbb{D}\right\} and components outside the space spanned by these channel vectors only increase the objective function in (23). This concludes the proof. ∎

Lemma 3 describes a genie-aided solution for the MMSE scheme: assume that set 𝔻𝔻\mathbb{D} is known to us. MMSE coordination is then readily found as follows: we first set,

𝐦⋆superscript𝐦⋆\displaystyle\mathbf{m}^{\star} =argmin𝐦∈ℂN​∑ℓ∈𝔻|𝐦𝖳​𝐡ℓ​P−ϕℓ|2+σ2​‖𝐦‖2absentsubscriptargmin𝐦superscriptℂ𝑁subscriptℓ𝔻superscriptsuperscript𝐦𝖳subscript𝐡ℓ𝑃subscriptitalic-ϕℓ2superscript𝜎2superscriptnorm𝐦2\displaystyle=\operatorname*{argmin}_{\mathbf{m}\in\mathbb{C}^{N}}\sum_{\ell\in\mathbb{D}}\left|\mathbf{m}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{h}_{\ell}\sqrt{P}-\phi_{\ell}\right|^{2}+\sigma^{2}\left\|\mathbf{m}\right\|^{2} (24)
=argmin𝐦∈ℂN‖P​𝐇𝔻𝖳​𝐦−ϕ𝔻‖2+σ2​‖𝐦‖2absentsubscriptargmin𝐦superscriptℂ𝑁superscriptnorm𝑃superscriptsubscript𝐇𝔻𝖳𝐦subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝔻2superscript𝜎2superscriptnorm𝐦2\displaystyle=\operatorname*{argmin}_{\mathbf{m}\in\mathbb{C}^{N}}\left\|\sqrt{P}\mathbf{H}_{\mathbb{D}}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{m}-\boldsymbol{\phi}_{\mathbb{D}}\right\|^{2}+\sigma^{2}\left\|\mathbf{m}\right\|^{2} (25)
=†1P​𝐇𝔻∗​(𝐇𝔻𝖳​𝐇𝔻∗+σ2P​𝐈D)−1​ϕ𝔻,superscript†absent1𝑃superscriptsubscript𝐇𝔻superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐇𝔻𝖳superscriptsubscript𝐇𝔻superscript𝜎2𝑃subscript𝐈𝐷1subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝔻\displaystyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\dagger}}{{=}}\frac{1}{\sqrt{P}}\mathbf{H}_{\mathbb{D}}^{*}\left(\mathbf{H}_{\mathbb{D}}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{H}_{\mathbb{D}}^{*}+\frac{\sigma^{2}}{P}\mathbf{I}_{D}\right)^{-1}\boldsymbol{\phi}_{\mathbb{D}}, (26)

where 𝐇𝔻∈ℂN×Dsubscript𝐇𝔻superscriptℂ𝑁𝐷\mathbf{H}_{\mathbb{D}}\in\mathbb{C}^{N\times D} with D=|𝔻|𝐷𝔻D=\left|\mathbb{D}\right| is the reduced form of the channel matrix 𝐇𝐇\mathbf{H} including only the columns of 𝐇𝐇\mathbf{H} whose indices are in 𝔻𝔻\mathbb{D}. Similarly, the vector ϕ𝔻subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝔻\boldsymbol{\phi}_{\mathbb{D}} is the reduced form of ϕbold-italic-ϕ\boldsymbol{\phi}. The identity ††\dagger further follows the regularized ZF solution. Having 𝐦⋆superscript𝐦⋆\mathbf{m}^{\star}, we then set bℓ⋆=Psuperscriptsubscript𝑏ℓ⋆𝑃b_{\ell}^{\star}=\sqrt{P} for ℓ∈𝔻ℓ𝔻\ell\in\mathbb{D} and the remaining scaling coefficients according to (2) in Lemma 2.

The results of Lemmas 1-3 imply that the main challenge in MMSE coordination is to find set 𝔻𝔻\mathbb{D}, i.e., the devices that need to transmit with maximum power. This is in general an integer programming problem. In Section  VI, we propose a low-complexity algorithm to approximate this set. To state this algorithm, we need first to present some analytical results on ZF coordination. In the light of these results, we present our low-complexity algorithm for MMSE coordination.

IV ZF Coordination for OTA-FL

ZF coordination sets the first term of the aggregation error to zero while keeping the transmit powers below P𝑃P. This leads to a closed-form scaling coefficients, c.f. (16), and an expression for the receiver in terms of a quadratic programming problem, i.e., (15). The ZF scheme can be seen as a mismatched version of MMSE coordination in which the PS postulates noise to be zero-variance. In this section, we invoke this interpretation and extend the analytic results of Section III to ZF coordination.

We start the analysis by deriving a genie-aided form of ZF coordination. To this end, we partition the devices into subsets 𝔻zfsuperscript𝔻zf\mathbb{D}^{\mathrm{zf}} and 𝔻¯zfsuperscript¯𝔻zf\bar{\mathbb{D}}^{\mathrm{zf}} with the former denoting those that transmit with maximum power P𝑃P and the latter being its complement. Similar to 𝔻𝔻\mathbb{D}, the set 𝔻zfsuperscript𝔻zf{\mathbb{D}^{{\mathrm{zf}}}} cannot be empty.

Lemma 4.

With ZF coordination in the network, there is at least one device that transmits with the maximum power P𝑃P.

Proof.

The proof is given by contradiction following identical steps as in the proof of Lemma 1. ∎

We can further develop a similar result as in Lemma 3 for ZF coordination: if one knows 𝔻zfsuperscript𝔻zf\mathbb{D}^{\mathrm{zf}}; then, the receiver 𝐦zfsuperscript𝐦zf\mathbf{m}^{\rm zf} is given by the following lemma.

Lemma 5.

Given 𝔻zfsuperscript𝔻zf{\mathbb{D}^{{\mathrm{zf}}}}, the receiver 𝐦zfsuperscript𝐦zf\mathbf{m}^{\rm zf} in (15) is given by

𝐦zf=1P​𝐇𝔻zf∗​(𝐇𝔻zf𝖳​𝐇𝔻zf∗)−1​ϕ𝔻zf,superscript𝐦zf1𝑃superscriptsubscript𝐇superscript𝔻zfsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐇superscript𝔻zf𝖳superscriptsubscript𝐇superscript𝔻zf1subscriptbold-italic-ϕsuperscript𝔻zf\displaystyle\mathbf{m}^{\rm zf}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{P}}\mathbf{H}_{\mathbb{D}^{{\mathrm{zf}}}}^{*}\left(\mathbf{H}_{\mathbb{D}^{{\mathrm{zf}}}}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{H}_{\mathbb{D}^{{\mathrm{zf}}}}^{*}\right)^{-1}\boldsymbol{\phi}_{\mathbb{D}^{{\mathrm{zf}}}}, (27)

and the aggregation error is

ϵ​(𝐦zf,𝐁zf)=σ2P​ϕ𝔻zf𝖳​(𝐇𝔻zf𝖳​𝐇𝔻zf∗)−1​ϕ𝔻zf.italic-ϵsuperscript𝐦zfsuperscript𝐁zfsuperscript𝜎2𝑃superscriptsubscriptbold-italic-ϕsuperscript𝔻zf𝖳superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐇superscript𝔻zf𝖳superscriptsubscript𝐇superscript𝔻zf1subscriptbold-italic-ϕsuperscript𝔻zf\displaystyle\epsilon\left(\mathbf{m}^{\rm zf},\mathbf{B}^{\rm zf}\right)=\frac{\sigma^{2}}{P}\boldsymbol{\phi}_{\mathbb{D}^{{\mathrm{zf}}}}^{\mathsf{T}}\left(\mathbf{H}_{\mathbb{D}^{{\mathrm{zf}}}}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{H}_{\mathbb{D}^{{\mathrm{zf}}}}^{*}\right)^{-1}\boldsymbol{\phi}_{\mathbb{D}^{{\mathrm{zf}}}}. (28)
Proof.

The ZF scheme is a mismatched MMSE coordination scheme in which σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} is postulated to be zero. This implies that Lemma 3 is also valid for the ZF scheme by replacing 𝔻𝔻\mathbb{D} with 𝔻zfsuperscript𝔻zf{\mathbb{D}^{{\mathrm{zf}}}}. Consequently, 𝐦zfsuperscript𝐦zf\mathbf{m}^{\mathrm{zf}} is given in terms of 𝔻zfsuperscript𝔻zf{\mathbb{D}^{{\mathrm{zf}}}} from (26) by replacing 𝔻𝔻\mathbb{D} with 𝔻zfsuperscript𝔻zf{\mathbb{D}^{{\mathrm{zf}}}} and setting σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} to zero. The aggregation error is then derived by substituting 𝐦zfsuperscript𝐦zf\mathbf{m}^{\mathrm{zf}} into (14). ∎

Lemma 5 implies the same fact about ZF coordination: similar to the MMSE scheme, the root problem in ZF coordination is to find those devices that transmit with the maximum power. It is worth mentioning that 𝔻𝔻\mathbb{D} and 𝔻zfsuperscript𝔻zf{\mathbb{D}^{{\mathrm{zf}}}} are in general not identical; nevertheless, the problem of finding these discrete subsets also reduces to an integer programming problem. For the sake of brevity, we refer to this root problem as the subset selection problem in the remaining of this paper.

V Subset Selection for ZF Coordination

The computational complexity of the subset selection problem grows exponentially with the number of devices: there are in total 2L−1superscript2𝐿12^{L}-1 possible choices555Note that the empty set does not occur according to Lemmas 1 and 4. for the device subset. Thus, the complete search algorithm poses exponential complexity to the system. We hence look for a low-complexity approach to find a good choice for the device subset.

We start the derivations by defining the concept of a feasible setting for ZF coordination:

Definition 1.

The receiver 𝐦𝐦\mathbf{m} and coefficients {bℓ}subscript𝑏ℓ\left\{b_{\ell}\right\} describe a feasible ZF setting, if |bℓ|2≤Psuperscriptsubscript𝑏ℓ2𝑃\left|b_{\ell}\right|^{2}\leq P and 𝐦𝖳​𝐡ℓ​bℓ=ϕℓsuperscript𝐦𝖳subscript𝐡ℓsubscript𝑏ℓsubscriptitalic-ϕℓ\mathbf{m}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{h}_{\ell}b_{\ell}=\phi_{\ell} for ℓ∈[L]ℓdelimited-[]𝐿\ell\in\left[L\right].

A feasible ZF setting only applies ZF on the received signal, i.e., it sets the first term in the right hand side of (9) zero, and ignores the optimization in (15) that minimizes the aggregation error. In this respect, we can see the ZF coordination scheme as a feasible ZF setting with minimal aggregation error. It is further easy to show that a feasible ZF setting is uniquely specified by its set of devices transmitting with power P𝑃P:

Lemma 6.

Let 𝕊𝕊\mathbb{S} denote the set of devices which transmit with power P𝑃P in a feasible ZF setting with receiver 𝐦𝐦\mathbf{m} and scaling coefficients {bℓ}subscript𝑏ℓ\left\{b_{\ell}\right\}. Then, 𝐦𝐦\mathbf{m} is given by

𝐦=1P​𝐇𝕊∗​(𝐇𝕊𝖳​𝐇𝕊∗)−1​ϕ𝕊,𝐦1𝑃superscriptsubscript𝐇𝕊superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐇𝕊𝖳superscriptsubscript𝐇𝕊1subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝕊\displaystyle\mathbf{m}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{P}}\mathbf{H}_{\mathbb{S}}^{*}\left(\mathbf{H}_{\mathbb{S}}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{H}_{\mathbb{S}}^{*}\right)^{-1}\boldsymbol{\phi}_{\mathbb{S}}, (29)

and bℓsubscript𝑏ℓb_{\ell} is determined from (13) for ℓ∈[L]ℓdelimited-[]𝐿\ell\in\left[L\right].

Proof.

The proof takes exactly the same steps as in Lemma 5. We hence skip the proof. ∎

Considering the definition, we now focus on the number of feasible ZF setting for coordination Czfsuperscript𝐶zfC^{\mathrm{zf}}. Following Lemmas 1 and 4, it is readily concluded that

Czf≤2L−1.superscript𝐶zfsuperscript2𝐿1\displaystyle C^{\mathrm{zf}}\leq 2^{L}-1. (30)

It is further easy to show that Czfsuperscript𝐶zfC^{\mathrm{zf}} can be considerably smaller than 2L−1superscript2𝐿12^{L}-1: for a non-empty subset 𝕊⊆[L]𝕊delimited-[]𝐿\mathbb{S}\subseteq\left[L\right], determine 𝐦𝐦{\mathbf{m}} and bℓsubscript𝑏ℓb_{\ell} from Lemma 6. The scaling coefficients are however not guaranteed to satisfy the transmit power constraint. Thus, the described setting is not necessarily feasible for ZF coordination. This observation implies that not all the 2L−1superscript2𝐿12^{L}-1 settings determined by applying ZF over the choices of 𝕊𝕊\mathbb{S} describe a feasible ZF setting, and hence Czfsuperscript𝐶zfC^{\mathrm{zf}} can be in general considerably smaller than 2L−1superscript2𝐿12^{L}-1.

Considering the above behavior, an algorithmic approach for approximating the ZF scheme is to track down the feasible ZF settings (or at least a subset of them). If there are only a few of them, i.e., Czfsuperscript𝐶zfC^{\mathrm{zf}} is small; then, the ZF coordination scheme is readily found by a finite-dimensional search. The following theorem describes the conditions under which the feasible ZF settings and the ZF scheme are explicitly found.

Theorem 1.

Let s𝑠s be index of the device whose channel norm is smallest, i.e.,

s=argminℓ∈[L]‖𝐡ℓ‖,𝑠subscriptargminℓdelimited-[]𝐿normsubscript𝐡ℓ\displaystyle s=\operatorname*{argmin}_{\ell\in\left[L\right]}\left\|\mathbf{h}_{\ell}\right\|, (31)

and define gℓ=𝐡s𝖧​𝐡ℓ/ϕℓsubscriptgℓsuperscriptsubscript𝐡𝑠𝖧subscript𝐡ℓsubscriptitalic-ϕℓ{\mathrm{g}}_{\ell}=\mathbf{h}_{s}^{\mathsf{H}}\mathbf{h}_{\ell}/\phi_{\ell} for ℓ∈[L]ℓdelimited-[]𝐿\ell\in\left[L\right]. Assume that |gs|≤|gℓ|subscriptg𝑠subscriptgℓ\left|{\mathrm{g}}_{s}\right|\leq\left|{\mathrm{g}}_{\ell}\right| for all ℓ∈[L]ℓdelimited-[]𝐿\ell\in\left[L\right] with equality holding for devices in set 𝕊⊆[L]𝕊delimited-[]𝐿\mathbb{S}\subseteq\left[L\right]. Then, 𝔻zf=𝕊superscript𝔻zf𝕊{\mathbb{D}^{{\mathrm{zf}}}}=\mathbb{S}, i.e., only the device in 𝕊𝕊\mathbb{S} transmit with the maximum power P𝑃P. The ZF coordination scheme in this case is described with

𝐦zf=ϕs​𝐡s∗P​‖𝐡s‖2.superscript𝐦zfsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠superscriptsubscript𝐡𝑠𝑃superscriptnormsubscript𝐡𝑠2\displaystyle\mathbf{m}^{\mathrm{zf}}=\frac{\phi_{s}\mathbf{h}_{s}^{*}}{\sqrt{P}\left\|\mathbf{h}_{s}\right\|^{2}}. (32)
Proof.

We start the proof by showing that the given setting is feasible for ZF coordination. To this end, let 𝐦=𝐦zf𝐦superscript𝐦zf\mathbf{m}=\mathbf{m}^{\mathrm{zf}} as given in the theorem and bs=Psubscript𝑏𝑠𝑃b_{s}=\sqrt{P}. We first note that

𝐦𝖳​𝐡s​bs=ϕs,superscript𝐦𝖳subscript𝐡𝑠subscript𝑏𝑠subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠\displaystyle\mathbf{m}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{h}_{s}b_{s}=\phi_{s}, (33)

which satisfies the ZF constraint (13) for device s𝑠s. For other devices, we apply ZF by setting

bℓsubscript𝑏ℓ\displaystyle b_{\ell} =ϕℓ𝐦𝖳​𝐡ℓ=ϕℓ​‖𝐡s‖2ϕs​𝐡s𝖧​𝐡ℓ​P=gsgℓ​P.absentsubscriptitalic-ϕℓsuperscript𝐦𝖳subscript𝐡ℓsubscriptitalic-ϕℓsuperscriptnormsubscript𝐡𝑠2subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠superscriptsubscript𝐡𝑠𝖧subscript𝐡ℓ𝑃subscriptg𝑠subscriptgℓ𝑃\displaystyle=\frac{\phi_{\ell}}{\mathbf{m}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{h}_{\ell}}=\frac{\phi_{\ell}\left\|\mathbf{h}_{s}\right\|^{2}}{\phi_{s}\mathbf{h}_{s}^{\mathsf{H}}\mathbf{h}_{\ell}}\sqrt{P}=\frac{{\mathrm{g}}_{s}}{{\mathrm{g}}_{\ell}}\sqrt{P}. (34)

This is hence concluded that under the constraint |gs|≤|gℓ|subscriptg𝑠subscriptgℓ\left|{\mathrm{g}}_{s}\right|\leq\left|{\mathrm{g}}_{\ell}\right|, this ZF setting is feasible. Moreover, it is concluded that in this case, all devices with |gℓ|=|gs|subscriptgℓsubscriptg𝑠\left|{\mathrm{g}}_{\ell}\right|=\left|{\mathrm{g}}_{s}\right| transmit with power P𝑃P.

We now show that the described feasible ZF setting is in fact the ZF scheme with minimal aggregation error. To this end, let 𝐦zfsuperscript𝐦zf\mathbf{m}^{\mathrm{zf}} and {bℓzf}superscriptsubscript𝑏ℓzf\left\{b_{\ell}^{\mathrm{zf}}\right\} denote the receiver and scaling coefficients of the ZF scheme, respectively. We decompose 𝐦zfsuperscript𝐦zf\mathbf{m}^{\mathrm{zf}} in terms of its projection on 𝐡s∗superscriptsubscript𝐡𝑠\mathbf{h}_{s}^{*} and its component in the null space of 𝐡s∗superscriptsubscript𝐡𝑠\mathbf{h}_{s}^{*}, i.e.,

𝐦zf=c​𝐡s∗+c⟂​𝐡s⟂∗superscript𝐦zf𝑐superscriptsubscript𝐡𝑠subscript𝑐perpendicular-tosuperscriptsubscript𝐡𝑠perpendicular-toabsent\displaystyle\mathbf{m}^{\mathrm{zf}}=c\;\mathbf{h}_{s}^{*}+c_{\perp}\mathbf{h}_{s}^{\perp*} (35)

for some constants c𝑐c and c⟂subscript𝑐perpendicular-toc_{\perp} and 𝐡s⟂superscriptsubscript𝐡𝑠perpendicular-to\mathbf{h}_{s}^{\perp} being a vector orthogonal to 𝐡ssubscript𝐡𝑠\mathbf{h}_{s}, i.e., 𝐡s𝖧​𝐡s⟂=0superscriptsubscript𝐡𝑠𝖧superscriptsubscript𝐡𝑠perpendicular-to0\mathbf{h}_{s}^{\mathsf{H}}\mathbf{h}_{s}^{\perp}=0. To fulfill the ZF condition for device s𝑠s, we need to have 𝐦zf​𝖳​𝐡s=0superscript𝐦zf𝖳subscript𝐡𝑠0\mathbf{m}^{{\mathrm{zf}}\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{h}_{s}=0. This concludes that

c=ϕs‖𝐡s‖2​bs,𝑐subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠superscriptnormsubscript𝐡𝑠2subscript𝑏𝑠\displaystyle c=\frac{\phi_{s}}{\left\|\mathbf{h}_{s}\right\|^{2}b_{s}}, (36)

and noting that |bs|2≤Psuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑠2𝑃\left|b_{s}\right|^{2}\leq P, we should set

|c|≥ϕs‖𝐡s‖2​P.𝑐subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠superscriptnormsubscript𝐡𝑠2𝑃\displaystyle\left|c\right|\geq\frac{\phi_{s}}{\left\|\mathbf{h}_{s}\right\|^{2}\sqrt{P}}. (37)

Considering (14), we conclude that the aggregation error is

ϵ​(𝐦zf,{bℓzf})=σ2​(|c|2​‖𝐡s‖2+|c⟂|2​‖𝐡s⟂‖2)italic-ϵsuperscript𝐦zfsuperscriptsubscript𝑏ℓzfsuperscript𝜎2superscript𝑐2superscriptnormsubscript𝐡𝑠2superscriptsubscript𝑐perpendicular-to2superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐡𝑠perpendicular-to2\displaystyle\epsilon\left(\mathbf{m}^{\mathrm{zf}},\left\{b_{\ell}^{\mathrm{zf}}\right\}\right)=\sigma^{2}\left(\left|c\right|^{2}\;\left\|\mathbf{h}_{s}\right\|^{2}+\left|c_{\perp}\right|^{2}\left\|\mathbf{h}_{s}^{\perp}\right\|^{2}\right) (38)

that is minimized by setting |c|𝑐\left|c\right| to its lower bound in (37) and c⟂=0subscript𝑐perpendicular-to0c_{\perp}=0. This describes the feasible ZF setting with minimal aggregation error. Hence, the proof is concluded. ∎

Theorem 1 describes a sufficient condition under which the ZF scheme is determined closed-form. This condition is very likely to hold in practical scenarios in which few devices have significantly larger path-losses as compared with the others edge devices in the network. We consider an example of such a scenario throughout the numerical investigations. It is worth mentioning that in a homogeneous setting, i.e., ϕℓ=ϕsubscriptitalic-ϕℓitalic-ϕ\phi_{\ell}=\phi for ℓ∈[L]ℓdelimited-[]𝐿\ell\in\left[L\right], with a single-antenna PS, the sufficient condition in Theorem 1 always hold. This is obvious, since in this case only the device with weakest channel should transmit with the maximum power for ZF coordination666Note that for MMSE coordination, this is in general not true, as also shown for a mathematically-similar problem in [25]..

V-A ZF Coordination without Closed-Form Solution

If the sufficient condition in Theorem 1 does not hold, ZF coordination is found by searching over all feasible settings. This search procedure is exponentially hard. We hence develop a tractable algorithm which approximates the solution by polynomial complexity. In this respect, the following lemma, can be further useful to limit our search

Lemma 7.

If the condition in Theorem 1 does not hold; then, there are at least two devices which transmit with the maximum power P𝑃P in ZF coordination.

Proof.

The proof is readily given by contradiction. We hence skip it here. ∎

Considering Lemma 7 and the earlier results on ZF coordination, we can have the following statements about the optimal ZF scheme, when it is not given by Theorem 1:

  • •

    It is a feasible ZF setting.

  • •

    There are at least two devices with transmit power P𝑃P.

We further note that when all the devices transmit with power P𝑃P, a feasible ZF setting is always guaranteed to be determined: let bℓ=Psubscript𝑏ℓ𝑃b_{\ell}=\sqrt{P} for ℓ∈[L]ℓdelimited-[]𝐿\ell\in\left[L\right] and 𝐦𝐦\mathbf{m} to be the one given in Lemma 5 for 𝔻zf=[L]superscript𝔻zfdelimited-[]𝐿{\mathbb{D}^{{\mathrm{zf}}}}=\left[L\right]. These findings leads to this heuristic conclusion that a good approximate for the optimal ZF scheme is given by finding a feasible ZF setting with minimal number of devices transmitting with power P𝑃P. This heuristic conclusion leads us to a tree-based algorithm which is presented in the sequel.

Remark 1.

As mentioned in Section II, throughout the paper we assume N≥L𝑁𝐿N\geq L. This however does not restrict the scope of analyses. In fact, the derivations are further valid for settings with N<L𝑁𝐿N<L when we limit the subset selection problem to be solved for subsets with |𝕊|≤N𝕊𝑁\left|\mathbb{S}\right|\leq N.

V-B A Tree-Based Search Scheme

We now present a tree-based algorithm to find the optimal ZF scheme. Although its core idea comes from our heuristic conclusions, it is shown that with full complexity this algorithm is exact. Before we present the algorithm, we state the following lemma which serves as the analytical foundation of the tree-based algorithm:

Lemma 8.

Let (𝐦1,{b1​ℓ})subscript𝐦1subscript𝑏1ℓ\left(\mathbf{m}_{1},\left\{b_{1\ell}\right\}\right) and (𝐦2,{b2​ℓ})subscript𝐦2subscript𝑏2ℓ\left(\mathbf{m}_{2},\left\{b_{2\ell}\right\}\right) describe two feasible ZF setting for coordination. Denote the set of devices transmitting with power P𝑃P in these two settings with 𝕊1subscript𝕊1\mathbb{S}_{1} and 𝕊2subscript𝕊2\mathbb{S}_{2}, respectively. If 𝕊1⊆𝕊2subscript𝕊1subscript𝕊2\mathbb{S}_{1}\subseteq\mathbb{S}_{2}; then,

ϵ​(𝐦1,{b1​ℓ})≤ϵ​(𝐦2,{b2​ℓ}).italic-ϵsubscript𝐦1subscript𝑏1ℓitalic-ϵsubscript𝐦2subscript𝑏2ℓ\displaystyle\epsilon\left(\mathbf{m}_{1},\left\{b_{1\ell}\right\}\right)\leq\epsilon\left(\mathbf{m}_{2},\left\{b_{2\ell}\right\}\right). (39)
Proof.

The proof is readily concluded by the fact that the feasible region of the error minimization problem for subset 𝕊1subscript𝕊1\mathbb{S}_{1} contains the feasible region of the optimization problem defined with subset 𝕊2subscript𝕊2\mathbb{S}_{2}. This implies that the error obtained by the former minimization is smaller than the one in the latter. This concludes the proof. ∎

The above result implies that while searching for the optimal ZF coordination, those feasible ZF settings whose corresponding subsets include other feasible subsets can be further ignored777From Lemma 7, we further conclude that this search is restricted to |S|≥2𝑆2\left|S\right|\geq 2.. We hence can graphically visualize the search for the optimal feasible setting via a tree: consider a graph whose nodes denote those subsets of [L]delimited-[]𝐿\left[L\right] that describe feasible ZF settings. The node corresponding to 𝕊⊆[L]𝕊delimited-[]𝐿\mathbb{S}\subseteq\left[L\right] is connected to its children which are the subsets of 𝕊𝕊\mathbb{S} describing feasible ZF settings. Any set 𝕊≠[L]𝕊delimited-[]𝐿\mathbb{S}\neq\left[L\right] is further connected to its parent which is the feasible ZF set 𝕊~~𝕊\tilde{\mathbb{S}} containing 𝕊𝕊\mathbb{S}, i.e., 𝕊⊂𝕊~𝕊~𝕊\mathbb{S}\subset\tilde{\mathbb{S}}. If there are multiple choices for the parent of 𝕊𝕊\mathbb{S}; then, the set with largest cardinality is selected888If there are multiple nodes with largest cardinality, the we choose the parent among them at random.. This way we built a tree whose root is [L]delimited-[]𝐿\left[L\right] and whose cardinality of the sets corresponding to the nodes decreases as we move towards the leaves.

Example 1.

Consider a network with L=4𝐿4L=4 edge devices and N=5𝑁5N=5 antennas at the PS. Let ϕℓ=0.25subscriptitalic-ϕℓ0.25\phi_{\ell}=0.25 for all devices and P=1𝑃1P=1. The channel matrix is further as follows

𝐇=[0.300.460.390.19−0.550.32−0.520.040.32−0.14−0.48−0.110.720.13−0.370.180.21−0.36−1.32−0.23].𝐇matrix0.300.460.390.190.550.320.520.040.320.140.480.110.720.130.370.180.210.361.320.23\displaystyle\mathbf{H}=\begin{bmatrix}0.30&0.46&0.39&0.19\\ -0.55&0.32&-0.52&0.04\\ 0.32&-0.14&-0.48&-0.11\\ 0.72&0.13&-0.37&0.18\\ 0.21&-0.36&-1.32&-0.23\\ \end{bmatrix}. (40)

The ZF tree for this network is shown in Fig. 1. As observed, the root is {1,2,3,4}1234\left\{1,2,3,4\right\}.

Lemma 8 implies that the optimal ZF scheme with minimal aggregation error is among the leaves of the tree representing ZF feasible settings. Therefore, the problem of finding the optimal ZF scheme reduces to a search for the leaf with minimal error, i.e., the leaf with minimal norm of the receiver. It is worth mentioning that this search is still exponentially complex, since in general construction of the tree requires 2L−1superscript2𝐿12^{L}-1 feasibility checks. Its visual representation however describes a tractable approximation approach: starting from the root, we move towards the leaves in a step-wise fashion. In each step, we go from a parent to the child whose aggregation error is minimum among all the children. The search is finally over as we arrive at a leaf. This leaf is taken as the approximate of the solution.

V-C Approximate ZF Coordination

The proposed tree-based search lead to an approximation of ZF coordination which we refer to as approximate ZF (AZF). The details on this algorithm are as follows:

  1. 1.

    We initiate the search at the root of the tree by setting 𝕊(0)=[L]superscript𝕊0delimited-[]𝐿\mathbb{S}^{(0)}=\left[L\right]. The initial receiver 𝐦(0)superscript𝐦0\mathbf{m}^{(0)} and scaling coefficients are further found via Lemma 6.

  2. 2.

    At step i𝑖i, we consider all subsets of 𝕊(i)superscript𝕊𝑖\mathbb{S}^{(i)} that differ with 𝕊(i)superscript𝕊𝑖\mathbb{S}^{(i)} in only one element. For each subset, we determine the receiver from 𝐦(i)superscript𝐦𝑖\mathbf{m}^{(i)} and the corresponding channel vectors via rank-one update of matrix inverse; see [26]. We then calculate the scaling coefficients and check if they satisfy the transmit power constraint. If the power constraint is satisfied, we collect the subset as a feasible ZF subset of 𝕊(i)superscript𝕊𝑖\mathbb{S}^{(i)}.

  3. 3.

    Among the feasible ZF subsets of 𝕊(i)superscript𝕊𝑖\mathbb{S}^{(i)}, we set 𝕊(i+1)superscript𝕊𝑖1\mathbb{S}^{(i+1)} to be the one whose receiver has minimal norm.

The algorithm stops at step iTsubscript𝑖Ti_{\rm T}, where there is no feasible ZF subsets for the set 𝕊(iT)superscript𝕊subscript𝑖T\mathbb{S}^{(i_{\rm T})}.

The AZF scheme needs to search among L​(L+1)/2𝐿𝐿12L\left(L+1\right)/2 subsets in the worst-case scenario, and hence is computationally tractable. It can be further extended by considering multiple dominant paths of the tree. Such an extension can potentially lead to a more accurate approximation of the ZF scheme at the expense of higher computational complexity.

VI Subset Selection for MMSE Coordination

We now get back to the MMSE scheme and utilize the framework developed for ZF coordination to design a tractable algorithm for approximating the MMSE scheme. We start the derivations by defining the less-intuitive concept of a feasible MMSE setting. Before stating the definition, let us look back to the key properties of the MMSE scheme: from Lemmas 1 and 2, we know that the scaling coefficients in this scheme are either P𝑃\sqrt{P} or satisfy the ZF constraint. We further note that given the set of devices transmitting with power P𝑃P, the receiver can be found via (26). These features are dual to those satisfied by the ZF scheme. We hence invoke Definition 1 and define a feasible setting for MMSE coordination as follows:

Definition 2.

Consider the subset of devices 𝕊⊆[L]𝕊delimited-[]𝐿\mathbb{S}\subseteq\left[L\right] whose cardinality is |𝕊|=S𝕊𝑆\left|\mathbb{S}\right|=S. Let 𝐦𝐦\mathbf{m} be

𝐦=1P​𝐇𝕊∗​(𝐇𝕊𝖳​𝐇𝕊∗+σ2P​𝐈S)−1​ϕ𝕊.𝐦1𝑃superscriptsubscript𝐇𝕊superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐇𝕊𝖳superscriptsubscript𝐇𝕊superscript𝜎2𝑃subscript𝐈𝑆1subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝕊\displaystyle\mathbf{m}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{P}}\mathbf{H}_{\mathbb{S}}^{*}\left(\mathbf{H}_{\mathbb{S}}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{H}_{\mathbb{S}}^{*}+\frac{\sigma^{2}}{P}\mathbf{I}_{S}\right)^{-1}\boldsymbol{\phi}_{\mathbb{S}}. (41)

Let |bℓ|=Psubscript𝑏ℓ𝑃\left|b_{\ell}\right|=\sqrt{P} for ℓ∈𝕊ℓ𝕊\ell\in\mathbb{S} and determine bℓsubscript𝑏ℓb_{\ell} for ℓ∉𝕊ℓ𝕊\ell\notin\mathbb{S} from the equation 𝐦𝖳​𝐡ℓ​bℓ=ϕℓsuperscript𝐦𝖳subscript𝐡ℓsubscript𝑏ℓsubscriptitalic-ϕℓ\mathbf{m}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{h}_{\ell}b_{\ell}=\phi_{\ell}. The set 𝕊𝕊\mathbb{S} is said to describe a feasible MMSE setting for coordination, if |bℓ|2<Psuperscriptsubscript𝑏ℓ2𝑃\left|b_{\ell}\right|^{2}<P for ℓ∉𝕊ℓ𝕊\ell\notin\mathbb{S}.

Lemmas 1 and 2 along with (26) imply that the subset of devices transmitting with power P𝑃P in the MMSE scheme, i.e., 𝔻𝔻\mathbb{D}, describes a feasible MMSE setting. In other words, similar to ZF coordination, this definition relaxes the MMSE scheme by dropping the optimality constraint. We next follow the same steps as for ZF coordination to show that the MMSE scheme is given by searching over the tree of feasible settings for the smallest subset.

VI-A Properties of Feasible MMSE Settings

Similar to Theorem 1, a sufficient condition can be derived for MMSE coordination, under which the set 𝔻𝔻\mathbb{D}, and thus the MMSE scheme, is determined in closed-form.

Theorem 2.

Let s𝑠s be index of the device whose channel norm is smallest, i.e.,

s=argminℓ∈[L]‖𝐡ℓ‖.𝑠subscriptargminℓdelimited-[]𝐿normsubscript𝐡ℓ\displaystyle s=\operatorname*{argmin}_{\ell\in\left[L\right]}\left\|\mathbf{h}_{\ell}\right\|. (42)

Define the vector 𝐠𝐠\mathbf{g} as

𝐠=𝚽−1​(𝐇𝖧​𝐡s+σ2P​𝐨s),𝐠superscript𝚽1superscript𝐇𝖧subscript𝐡𝑠superscript𝜎2𝑃subscript𝐨𝑠\displaystyle\mathbf{g}=\boldsymbol{\Phi}^{-1}\left(\mathbf{H}^{\mathsf{H}}\mathbf{h}_{s}+\frac{\sigma^{2}}{P}\mathbf{o}_{s}\right), (43)

where 𝚽=Diag​{ϕℓ}𝚽Diagsubscriptitalic-ϕℓ\boldsymbol{\Phi}=\mathrm{Diag}\left\{\phi_{\ell}\right\} and 𝐨s∈{0,1}Lsubscript𝐨𝑠superscript01𝐿\mathbf{o}_{s}\in\left\{0,1\right\}^{L} is a vector with a single non-zero entry at index s𝑠s. Denote the entry ℓℓ\ell of 𝐠𝐠\mathbf{g} with gℓsubscriptgℓ{\mathrm{g}}_{\ell} and assume that |gs|≤|gℓ|subscriptg𝑠subscriptgℓ\left|{\mathrm{g}}_{s}\right|\leq\left|{\mathrm{g}}_{\ell}\right| for all ℓ∈[L]ℓdelimited-[]𝐿\ell\in\left[L\right] with equality holding for devices in set 𝕊⊆[L]𝕊delimited-[]𝐿\mathbb{S}\subseteq\left[L\right]. Then, 𝔻=𝕊𝔻𝕊\mathbb{D}=\mathbb{S}, i.e., only the device in 𝕊𝕊\mathbb{S} transmit with the maximum power P𝑃P. The MMSE coordination scheme in this case is described with

𝐦⋆=P​ϕs​𝐡s∗P​‖𝐡s‖2+σ2.superscript𝐦⋆𝑃subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠superscriptsubscript𝐡𝑠𝑃superscriptnormsubscript𝐡𝑠2superscript𝜎2\displaystyle\mathbf{m}^{\star}=\frac{\sqrt{P}\phi_{s}\mathbf{h}_{s}^{*}}{P\left\|\mathbf{h}_{s}\right\|^{2}+\sigma^{2}}. (44)
Proof.

The proof follows similar steps as those taken for the proof of Theorem 1. We hence skip the details. ∎

Theorem 1 describes the sufficient condition for tractable calculation of the MMSE scheme. For networks which do not satisfy this condition, one can show that similar findings, as those given in Sections V-A and V-B for ZF coordination, are reported as well in this case. In particular, we can show that feasible MMSE settings reduce in aggregation error as their corresponding subset of devices with maximum transmit power shrinks.

Lemma 9.

Let (𝐦1,{b1​ℓ})subscript𝐦1subscript𝑏1ℓ\left(\mathbf{m}_{1},\left\{b_{1\ell}\right\}\right) and (𝐦2,{b2​ℓ})subscript𝐦2subscript𝑏2ℓ\left(\mathbf{m}_{2},\left\{b_{2\ell}\right\}\right) describe two feasible MMSE settings for coordination whose corresponding subsets are 𝕊1subscript𝕊1\mathbb{S}_{1} and 𝕊2subscript𝕊2\mathbb{S}_{2}, respectively. If 𝕊1⊆𝕊2subscript𝕊1subscript𝕊2\mathbb{S}_{1}\subseteq\mathbb{S}_{2}; then,

ϵ​(𝐦1,{b1​ℓ})≤ϵ​(𝐦2,{b2​ℓ}).italic-ϵsubscript𝐦1subscript𝑏1ℓitalic-ϵsubscript𝐦2subscript𝑏2ℓ\displaystyle\epsilon\left(\mathbf{m}_{1},\left\{b_{1\ell}\right\}\right)\leq\epsilon\left(\mathbf{m}_{2},\left\{b_{2\ell}\right\}\right). (45)
Proof.

The proof is similar to the proof of Lemma 8. ∎

VI-B Approximate MMSE Coordination

Lemma 9 indicates that the MMSE scheme can be found by searching for the MMSE feasible setting with smallest subset. We hence follow the same approach as in Section V-B and build the tree of feasible MMSE schemes. Due to its similarity, we skip the definition of the tree and refer the reader to Section V-B. We now approximately find the MMSE scheme by moving step-wise from the root towards the leaves while in each step we choose the child whose aggregation error is minimum among all the children connected to the parent.

The proposed tree-based search algorithm for MMSE coordination can be summarized as follows:

  1. 1.

    We initiate the search at the root of the tree by setting 𝕊(0)=[L]superscript𝕊0delimited-[]𝐿\mathbb{S}^{(0)}=\left[L\right]. The initial receiver 𝐦(0)superscript𝐦0\mathbf{m}^{(0)} and scaling coefficients are further found from Definition 2.

  2. 2.

    At step i𝑖i, we consider all subsets of 𝕊(i)superscript𝕊𝑖\mathbb{S}^{(i)} that differ with 𝕊(i)superscript𝕊𝑖\mathbb{S}^{(i)} in only one element. For each subset, we determine the receiver from 𝐦(i)superscript𝐦𝑖\mathbf{m}^{(i)} and the channel vectors via rank-one update. We then calculate the scaling coefficients and check if they describe a feasible MMSE setting.

  3. 3.

    Among the feasible MMSE subsets of 𝕊(i)superscript𝕊𝑖\mathbb{S}^{(i)}, we set 𝕊(i+1)superscript𝕊𝑖1\mathbb{S}^{(i+1)} to be the one whose aggregation error is minimum.

The algorithm stops, when no feasible MMSE subsets is found. We refer to this algorithm in the sequel as approximate MMSE (AMMSE) scheme.

VII Numerical results

In the section, we examine the efficiency of the proposed algorithms through numerical experiments. To this end, we consider a simple network whose uplink channels experience a standard i.i.d. Rayleigh fading process with fixed path-loss. The channel coefficients are hence written as hℓ,n=tℓ​fℓ,nsubscriptℎℓ𝑛subscript𝑡ℓsubscript𝑓ℓ𝑛h_{\ell,n}=t_{\ell}f_{\ell,n}, where fℓ,n∼𝒞​𝒩​(0,1/N)similar-tosubscript𝑓ℓ𝑛𝒞𝒩01𝑁f_{\ell,n}\sim\mathcal{CN}(0,1/N) models small-scale fading, and tℓsubscript𝑡ℓt_{\ell} captures the path-loss between the PS and device ℓℓ\ell. We further assume an FL setting in which ϕℓ=1/Lsubscriptitalic-ϕℓ1𝐿\phi_{\ell}=1/L for ℓ∈[L]ℓdelimited-[]𝐿\ell\in\left[L\right].

In this network, we coordinate the devices using the proposed scheme, i.e., AZF and AMMSE. For sake of comparison, we further evaluate the optimal ZF and MMSE schemes by performing a complete search over the leaves of their corresponding trees. To keep the simulations for the optimum case tractable, we limit the number of devices in the network.

VII-A Coordination Performance

Fig. 2 shows the aggregation error against the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) in the network, defined as SNR=P/σ2SNR𝑃superscript𝜎2\mathrm{SNR}={P}/{\sigma^{2}}, for L=4𝐿4L=4 and N=8𝑁8N=8. For this figure, the path-losses are set to tℓ=1subscript𝑡ℓ1t_{\ell}=1 for ℓ∈[L]ℓdelimited-[]𝐿\ell\in\left[L\right]. As the figure shows, for a small number of devices, the approximate schemes, i.e., AZF and AMMSE, perform optimally.

We next investigate the impact of network asymmetry on both the coordination approaches in Fig.  3, where we plot the same figure for two different scenarios: the first scenario is as the one considered in Fig. 2, and the other considers the setting in which the path-loss of one of the devices is 101010 dB below the others. As shown in the figure, ZF coordination is more sensitive to the non-uniformity of the path-losses as compared to the MMSE scheme. This is in particular severe at low SNRs which is often the case in current wireless networks.

As the next experiment, we plot the aggregation error against the load of the system that is defined as ξ=N/L𝜉𝑁𝐿\xi=N/L in Fig. 4. For numerical tractability of the optimal schemes, we set L=4𝐿4L=4. The SNR is further set to log⁡SNR=12SNR12\log\mathrm{SNR}=12 dB, and the path-loss is set to tℓ=1subscript𝑡ℓ1t_{\ell}=1 for ℓ∈[L]ℓdelimited-[]𝐿\ell\in\left[L\right]. As observed, the tree-base approximates closely track the optimal schemes. Furthermore, the gap between the optimal and approximated schemes shrinks as the load grows.

VII-B Complexity of the Proposed Schemes

As a metric of complexity, we define the check time to be the number of subsets being checked in the tree-based search of the algorithm. Fig. 5 and Fig. 6 show the average check time for AZF or AMMSE algorithms against the SNR and load, respectively. Here, L=4𝐿4L=4 and N=8𝑁8N=8, and the check time is averaged over multiple channel realizations. The devices are assumed to be uniformly distributed in the network, i.e., the path-loss is assumed to the same for all the devices. As the figures depict, the complexity of the AZF scheme only varies against the load, while the complexity of the AMMSE scheme scales with both the load and channel quality. The figures further demonstrate that the check time for AMMSE is always less than AZF. This is a favorable behavior, since AMMSE leads to less aggregation error, as well. Fig. 6 further implies that the average check time of both the algorithms reduces by growth of N𝑁N and converges to L+1𝐿1L+1. This follows the fact that at high system loads, the channel vectors become statistically orthogonal, and hence all the devices transmit with the maximum power. As the result, both the algorithms stop at the root, after checking the feasibility of their L𝐿L children.

As the last experiment, we investigate the impacts of a non-uniform distribution of the device in the network on tree-based search complexity. Fig. 7 shows the average check time for the same setting as in Fig. 6, when one of the devices is located, such that its path-loss is 101010 dB below the path-losses of the other devices. As the figure shows, this asymmetry increases even further the gap between the complexity of AZF and AMMSE leading to this conclusion that AMMSE proposes a more robust behavior as compared with the AZF.

VIII Conclusions

Low-complexity algorithms have been proposed for MMSE and ZF coordination in OTA-FL. The algorithms find efficient approximation of the optimal MMSE and ZF schemes using a tree-based search algorithm which solves the equivalent subset selection problem. Our numerical investigations depict that the proposed algorithms track closely the optimal schemes.

The analytical results of this study indicate that both the MMSE and ZF coordination schemes deal with the same level of hardness, while the former leads to a lower aggregation error. The numerical investigations further reveal that the tree-based approximation of MMSE coordination results in less computational complexity and more robustness as compared to the approximated ZF scheme. Considering the favorable behavior of the MMSE scheme with respect to performance and complexity, one concludes that MMSE is a better approach for device coordination in OTA-FL.
